relevance:
Relevance - measures how well the story matches its prompt.
1 — The story has no relationship with the prompt at all.
1.5 — The story only has a weak relationship with the prompt.
2 — The story roughly matches the prompt.
2.5 — The story matches the prompt, except for one or two small aspects.
3 — The story matches the prompt exactly.
coherence:
Coherence — measures whether the story makes sense.
1 — The story does not make sense at all. For instance, the setting and/or characters keep changing, and/or there is no understandable plot.
1.5 — Most of the story does not make sense.
2 — The story mostly makes sense but has some incoherences.
2.5 — The story almost makes sense overall, except for one or two small incoherences.
3 — The story makes sense from beginning to end.
empathy:
Empathy — measures how well you understood the characters’ emotions (regardless of whether you agreed with them).
1 — The characters seemed apathetic to you.
1.5 — At least one character slightly related to you on an emotional level.
2 — You recognized specific, but not necessarily strong, emotions (eg sadness,joy, fear. . . ) in at least one character.
2.5 — At least one character emotionally involved you, but minor details prevented you from completely relating to them.
3 — At least one character completely involved you on an emotional level.
surprise:
Surprise — measures how surprising the end of the story was.
1 — The ending seemed completely obvious from the start, or doesn’t make any sense at all.
1.5 — The ending was easily predictable after a few sentences.
2 — The ending was predictable after half of the story.
2.5 — The ending surprised you, but would have been difficult to predict.
3 — The ending surprised you, and still seemed as if it could very reasonably have been predicted, ie, there were enough clues in the story.
engagement:
Engagement — measures how much you engaged with the story.
1 — You found the story boring and were glad it was over.
1.5 — You found one or two things interesting in the story, but no more.
2 — The story was mildly interesting.
2.5 — The story almost kept you engaged until the end.
3 — You were so engaged that you wished there was a sequel.
complexity:
Complexity — measures how elaborate the story is.
1 — The setting of the story is extremely simple: it only involves one or two characters or concepts.
1.5 — The setting of the story is simple: one or two characters, a simple plot, maybe an indication of time or location.
2 — The story is somewhat developed: it involves at least one of the following: complex concepts, realistic characters, an intricate plot, an underlying history or circumstances, precise descriptions.
2.5 — The story is developed: it involves at least two of the following: complex concepts, realistic characters, an intricate plot, an underlying history or circumstances, precise descriptions.
3 — The story is well thought-out: it involves at least three of the following:complex concepts, realistic characters, an intricate plot, an underlying history or circumstances, precise descriptions.
